Cooking on coated/chemically treated aluminum, steel, stone, or glass cookware is poisonous to your health as the chemicals and coatings break down over time and seep into your food. Aluminum cookware also releases toxic chemicals into your food over 450°F. Use uncoated cast iron, stainless steel, or glass cookware. You should also use only stainless steel or natural wood utensils while cooking. It will save your life.

My beef about a certain brand of non-stick cookware was the Aluminum was too thin and the pans would warp as soon as they got hot on the stove.
It was a 12" deep frying pan. it weighed 1lb., 6.4 ounces and would warp even on low to medium heat.
I decided to buy a new one, and it actually felt heavier that the first one. It weighs 1lb. 7.8 ounces and does not warp even on high heat. Thicker Aluminum.
Bought at Walmart and the Brand name starts with "F". YouTube will delete the comment if I name the brand.

Teflon pans:
Have to be replaced once a year.
Leeches into your food long before it starts to peel.
Wasteful.
Horrible for the environment.
Horrible for your budget.
Causes cancer.
Makes food taste like shit.

Stainless steel pans:
Same price.
Significantly less so, if bought used.
The absolute safest and most leech-free way to prepare food.
Lets food taste like food.
Never needs to be replaced.
Can be used with any recipe.
Can be used in the oven if it has a metal handle.
Can go in the dishwasher.
Lasts functionally forever.
Can be passed down through the generations.
Eventually breaks down into cobalt.
Could then be sold for a fortune.

Technically you could use the same stainless steel pan your whole life, if you don't mind washing it after every single meal. I mean you still have to either way, but it's nice to have more than one.

At low temperatures (under 260C/500F) this coating is fine, but if you use high smoke point oils (refined safflower and avocado) you can go past 260C before they begin to smoke, at which point the coating begins breaking down.
Even at lower temperatures the coating is slowly degrading over time and these pans only last a few years before they lose enough of it to start sticking to foods. Best alternative is a ceramic coated pan (Greenpan is one option), only thing is you must be careful with it, no metal tools, hand washing only and don’t fry with olive oil (it burns too quickly).
Of course we dont mention how insanely toxic these chemicals are
